Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a zelda-style RPG Adventure game currently available on Steam. In Oceanhorn you play as a boy who's father has left him a notebook and a mysterious necklace, you read the notebook and follow in your father's footsteps in attempting to slay the legendary Oceanhorn. In order to be able to defeat Oceanhorn you must travel the length and bredth of the Uncharted Seas to find ancient artifacts and powerful magic all while solving puzzles and fighting enemies.

Just to say I have actually played the game longer than Steam says but due to disconnecting it hasn't saved all of my progress.

+Nice graphics which are bright and colourful
+A large map filled with many large islands for you to explore

+Outstanding soundtrack
+Quite a lot of items to unlock as you progress through the game

+The game's puzzles are challenging without being painfully difficult
+Nice variety of enemies
+Simple combat system which for the most part is good (I'll come back to this later)

-The story isn't particularly interesting
-I experienced a lot of framerate slow downs to pretty much single digits, judging from other reviews this is a problem for more than just me
-Sailing between islands is pretty dull as you can't steer your ship, only shoot objects with a gun you unlock and these sections cannot be skipped

Worth a mention:
-Oceanhorn was originally an iOS game which has now been ported to PC which could explain some of the performance issues

8

reviewText:
This is a mobile port and it definitely shows. The game is pretty enough, voice acting is decent, but the gameplay itself is dull. The controls feel clunky, especially in combat where your hits do not always register if you attack the enemy too fast. Magic takes too long to be useful most of the time, and even when it is needed it feels underwhelming. An item you get lets you jump across small gaps and dodge roll, both of which are keyed to the same button. The game will let you fall from areas up to a certain height, which means you can be doing a timed puzzle and then inadvertantly (and commonly) dodge roll instead of jumping to the next platform and have to do the entire thing over.

Damage is inconsistent, with bombs doing massive damage to some enemies but barely a scratch to others... and yet those other enemies will take a big chunk of damage from a random pot thrown at them. Speaking of pots, you have to either throw, shoot them, or throw a bomb at them to break them... your sword is evidently the sword of not smashing pots.

Bosses are few and far between, and most are unimpressive. I died a few times to them, not because they were hard, but because of completely unavoidable attacks, the boss freezing (status, not game freezing) the mechanic to damage it and the only way to unfreeze it aside from letting it time out is your magic with the very long windup, or just poorly designed.

Travel between islands is set on pre-set paths, you tell the game to go and it drops you into a little shooting gallery where you spam the attack button to kill anything that gets in the way until you reach the island. On mobile I'm sure it was neat, tap to kill the things, but on pc its just feels like a boring, spam your mouse button and go add-on.

Overall, the game is probably very good on mobile platforms, but not a very good pc game, and comparing it to zelda is like comparing a perfectly cooked steak to a $1 Banquet microwave dinner.

reviewText:
Waking up during a stormy night you find your father has left, leaving a notebook and strange necklace behind. What happened? Where did he go? It's your job to find out.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JjkNpmvSuxU
Oceanhorn is a port of a mobile game from 2013, rather then being a direct port much effort has gone into remastering the game for PC. Was it worth the wait? YES. Graphically speaking it's just as amazing as the first time you may have played it. Adding 4k+ res, realtime AO, soft shadows, AA, higher draw distance and 60FPS support among other things. While the game played well with keyboard+mouse or controller, everything was completely rebindable.

Staying true to the Zelda formula while keeping a charm of its own, you travel the between islands on your ship gradually piecing together the story. Each island has it's own distinct themes and challenges while some just serve as hub points for restocking and gathering new information about undiscovered locations. Progress will result in level ups which unlocked a range of upgrades including a peashooter for firing off your ship. Later stages traveling becomes quite dangerous so these extra defenses are critical.

Dungeons generally consist of simple puzzles and key finding while backtracking to unlock areas you were unable to access earlier. Select islands contain boss fights and victory often rewarded unique abilities which also helped with opening secret areas. While you do spend much of your time traveling to locations already seen it's not a problem at all, as you will also find many new npcs and sidequests along the way.

Oceanhorn is a little on the easy side but the beauty of the entire package completely out weighs the lack of challenge. The game does ramp up in the later stages and you'll need to learn different attack patterns of enemies to guarantee success. Already mentioned the graphics are very distinct, the closest game to the mark would be Lili: Child of Geos (another decent phone port). With a captivating story, relaxing soundtrack and a whole bunch content to discover. For the asking price it's well worth the investment. Cheers.

Summary:
Oceanhorn tries so hard to be a good Zelda clone, that it forgets to be good at all the little things that make a Zelda game a good game.

After spending a lot of time with Oceanhorn, I can give a thorough and fair review.
To give the game it's due, I will present the good before the bad.

Pros:
-Great looking visuals (minus character models). Colorful, thoughtful, visually appealing.
-A great game for particular gamers (Legend of Zelda fans, completionists, collectors)
-Zelda for PC! VERY Wind-waker inspired, which is touching for the nostalgia.
-A good wealth of game for the price. Many achievements and collectibles.
-Sailing doesn't suck! A good idea to make it more of a mini-game than a chore.

Cons:
-This is a Legend of Zelda clone that doesn't add or improve upon it's base material. The characters, the story, the puzzles, are all generally unappealling and forgettable.

Games in notable concepts and mechanisms have been copied in the past with the aim of doing something different or better. Oceanhorn is not that game - it is unashamedly a Zelda clone. This point wouldn't be so bad if it Oceanhorn didn't go in the opposite direction at times and do things WORSE than Zelda - something to be examplified in further cons.

-Puzzles are not challenging, and are often an exercise in tedium.

Most puzzles are not difficult for the problem they present and how to solve them, but are often about a game element responding the way the player intends it to. This is further coupled with the next point...

-Oceanhorn is arbitrarily made trying and longer with backtracking.

The game presents very early several problems that can only be solved after having particular items, which isn't anything new. However, one vital item to solving these problems isn't obtained until the 11th hour of the game, which presents the player with the (reluctantly optional) task of spending hours backtracking through every location for collectibles, treasure, etc. Without this, the game would probably have been about half it's actual length towards full completion, and with that in mind I can easily add that it outstayed it's welcome.

-Bombs OP.

reviewText:
Landstalker meets The Legend of Zelda. There are obvious nods to The Wind Waker in the world setting and locales right down to an ocean landscape dotted with islands, but that did not stop Cornfox & Bros from developing their game the way they wanted. The isometric view harkens back to an era that has long since disappeared in the realm of Z-targeting and free roam cameras - a programming art that was funnily enough perfected in The Wind Waker.

The story starts off simple enough with a young man's father having disappeared in the search for Oceanhorn. The main character sets off with an interaction level akin to the Zelda titles; jars are picked up and smashed on the ground, grass blades are slashed, boulders are blown apart by bombs. However there is an enjoyable yet simple physical meat to the main character in Oceanhorn. Even something as basic as wading in water brings about a speed penalty. A sign that the developers pay attention to the minutia of videogames.

The graphics are gloriously bright and colourful. The story won't set your imagination alight with wonder but it does the job. And the music is outstanding - sooner or later you'll be humming and whistling to the overworld theme.

It's a pity that this game may fly under the radar despite the reception it could and should achieve. Games like this don't come around too often anymore considering the monopoly of Zelda, so don't be deceived by the smartphone game" approach by some commentators. Oceanhorn is a delight and I look forward to whatever else comes out from the Finnish caverns of Cornfox & Bros."

reviewText: Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas caused a splash when it dropped on iOS back in 2013. reviewText:
Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is an action adventure heavily inspired by The Legend of Zelda. To begin with the story, it's not anything special, so you'll just live with the fact that your father left you to destroy the expanding evil. As a good son, instead of being hateful, you become a powerful knight that will save the world and unite all races, surpassing your father.

But from what exactly you'll have to save the world? Well, from three types of steampunk machines and a possessed living fortress, and few native creatures like trolls or orcs, which also have pretty low variety. Overall, Oceanhorn is limited this way, as you'll meet just few distinct NPCs and beat them with one of two swords, bow, bomb or one of your five spells.

The steam page says it's also an RPG but I think that's overestimated. Even though there is a leveling system, there aren't many character levels and each level up brings you a passive bonus, e.g. increased amount of bombs or arrows you can hold. There isn't any inventory system and even though there is a currency system, you'll save money for later anyway, because only appealing items in shops are the (two) expensive ones. All cheap stuff in shops are arrows, bombs, mana or health refills but you won't need to buy these - anytime you are missing something, the game drops it for you from the next enemy, bush or vase.

Low difficulty is something that really disappointed me. All puzzles are laughably easy and neither the combat is challenging, especially after you claim the second sword. Bosses might seem scary but they are easy too, it's like they want you to win with a single repeating pattern: Do something to stun them, tap your slash button until they stand up, and repeat two more times.

There are height differences on islands but the level design is pretty limited, you can't even jump down the cliff if it's higher than a block. After about 5 hours of playtime, you'll at least learn to roll and jump between blocks close to each other. Anyway, the game holds your hand in most moments so nothing bad can happen to you and if you fail anyway, you just respawn at nearest checkpoint and dead enemies are still dead until you leave the location. The game also have problems with occasional crashes, it crashed every hour in average but it's not a big problem since the game saves your progress often.

It's not complex, it's not hard, so what? Oceanhorn feels like a food for completionists. It has a good amount of achievements and it motivates you to explore all the areas, to find every treasure (even though you know it'll contain useless junk like an old shoe). There are a lot of secret areas and there's also a well-made challenge system - Each discovered island shows you three new challenges that you can beat anywhere in the game. Those challenges varies from kill X enemies" through "drown your enemy" to "catch your first fish".

reviewText:
What happens when you take an all-too-familiar formula like Zelda, tweak it ever so much, release it on iOS, then eventually on PC? Well, you get Oceanhorn Monster of Uncharted Seas. What seems like a Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker clone with an isometric camera, Oceanhorn has a style all its own. From sailing the high seas, spelunking dungeons for new items, and defeating bosses in a “spot and exploit the weakness” motif; sure this does sound a lot like Wind Waker, but hey, if you’re going to be influenced from a game series, why not one of the most renouned and beloved? Bonus points for borrowing so heavily from one of the strongest games in said franchise.

No one who plays Oceanhorn will be able to deny the various Legend of Zelda inspirations throughout, but just because it has all of these various ideas and tropes in place, is that a bad thing? Yes and no. Yes because a lot of Zelda fans are rather tired of the same Zelda formula the recent games have instituted: go to dungeon, get a new item, use that item on the dungeon’s boss, repeat 6-8 times, learn midway through of a legend about a green tunic’d warrior that will save the land, exposition a bit more, Triforce wielders confront, roll credits. We realize that’s a snarky critique, but it’s also valid. Oceanhorn at least avoids a lot of these tired ideas and throws us back to a more retro Zelda premise. Those who have played the very first Legend of Zelda on NES will recall the game was rather obtuse and almost too open. Players load the game up and are thrust into a world, onto a screen that has three directions: north, west, and east, with a single cave wherein player will find a weapon (sound familiar, yet?). Oceanhorn feels more like a 1989 Zelda than anything else in terms of world design and instructions.

A few players may be turned off by the lack of hand-holding and direction in the opening hours, but for us here, it was a refreshing take. We’ve become spoiled by overly-simplistic tutorials and being lead through opening segments with lengthy cutscenes and explanations about the world around us. Oceanhorn does seem to abandon the uniqueness it begins with after a few hours and lean on the Zelda formula, but it’s done progressively, making it a forgivable sin. There’s still the “collect x number of relics and defeat the ultimate evil” blueprint in place, but the dungeon exploration and puzzle solving is there to prevent boredom from overwhelming the player.

The gameplay takes place on dense lands ranging from single-tiered isles to several levels of housing and dungeons. Don’t be fooled by an island’s size while sailing up to it, there’s typically more below the surface than shown. The scale is lesser than Wind Waker, but this is no short game; expect to spend 10-15 hours with Oceanhorn, with an extra few for those that aim to collect any and everything the islands hold within. Puzzles will range from block-moving to hitting ranged targets with arrows. It’s never anything too strenuous, but a few were noodle scratchers that provided “eureka” moments when solved. Boss battles aren’t too genre-defying, but are more complex than one would think an iOS-to-PC game would be. Most bosses require a specific strategy to affect them, and finding out that strategy while strafing and dodging can provide a sense of tension few Zelda games can even subject us to. Tight rooms and multi-powered bosses can keep players on their toes during a fight.

Visually and audibly Oceanhorn is a like-it-or-leave-it presentation. Just like with nearly every other aspect, the main character borrows heavily from Link, even seemingly borrowing his Skyward Sword garb minus the hat, to head out on this adventure. Characters look great, full of colors, design, and polish, but few enemy types and marginally different skin swaps of some of them leave a lot to be desired. Lush environments and dark, diluted dungeons accentuate each other very well, but only vary by the end rather than consistently throughout. Nearly every over world island is practically the same look with a different layout; at least every themed dungeon has a personality and appeal. Voicework and composition are impressive given the small staff at handling the game, with many cutscenes providing adequate storytelling and delivery. Music is acceptable, if not a tad bit safe in the end. As fun and upbeat few of the songs are, there’s little that keeps us coming back to listen to more after the fact. It’s passable, and the influences are there, but the music just doesn’t have that lasting appeal that comes with other games, and especially Zelda games.

What was probably a great iOS game, where aside from DS titles, there were not many Zelda-esque games on the market; Oceanhorn was a relief and refreshing. Hitting Steam and diving into the deep end where Zelda clones are a dime a dozen, this little trek has heart, but fails to sail far enough from the rest of the pack to standout for too long. If you have a Zelda itch to scratch while waiting for more, Oceanhorn can fill that need, but don’t expect new ideas, only tweaked presentations on acquainted themes. Oceanhorn has depth and should be explored for those who truly enjoy its implementations and setup, but do be reserved when raising your sails and setting out, the seas aren’t as “uncharted” as they would like you to believe.

YES

+ Its small differences and appeal is good for Zelda fans

+ Engaging gameplay and puzzle-solving

- It’s an unapologetic Zelda clone, through and through, so your mileage may vary

- It’s likely a more impressive handheld game, not a great idea to port PC with even more competitors to compete against

reviewText:
At first I took the subtleties of this game's story as a Zelda inspired creation. However, it wasn't long before I started to enjoy the game in it's own right. It reminded me more of an old Playstation game by the name of Alundra more than Legend of Zelda. There is as much exploration and puzzles as there is adventure and fighting. Oceanhorn's story doesn't take too long to get into and honestly if I put down the game for a few days I would forget what I had to do despite the ability to review previous cutscenes. It's a really cool isometric game that deals with exploring various islands in a water ridden world.

The story was solid and never deviated far from the main goal of finding your father and defeating Oceanhorn. There were side quests a plenty along the way that brought you a little closer to your goal. Some featuring puzzles that required very little thinking, quick or otherwise. The general fighting was simple but gave you a few ways to approach how you would kill enemies. Boss battles took a slight learning curve before understanding their combat patterns. What I find surprising in this adventure RPG was the pace that it went.

This wasn't by any means a long game. The majority of my time was spent backtracking to find stuff or remember to do one of the quests when I ran into a road block. Clues were scattered around areas that alluded to other locations which I'd ultimately neglect to explore, which made things tedious. I noticed a few things that could have improved my experience.

One of the things I would have liked was a notebook that maybe jotted semi useful information that you found on your journey so that maybe I could remember where the honey was located without having to go back to the source to get information on particular items needed to progress. Another thing that I found a little mundane about it was the actual traveling between islands. You don't have the freedom of navigating yourself rather you select a route that your boat moves along. I did appreciate the obstacles in the water that I had to be vigilant and shoot with my cannon but after the 10th time it was repetitive to the point of boring because there was so much back and forth travel happening. It would have also been nice if your character was able to interact with people he met on the sea. With so many islands you really wonder why the sea was so barren.

Despite the critical observations I did enjoy this game the time I did spend playing it. the visuals were beautiful the controls tight and the music was well done. The atmosphere and pace of the gameplay was all one note with the exception nearing the final boss. This would be a nice game for anyone interested in Zelda-esque adventure.

reviewText:
It's true: Despite its own graphical style, isometic viewpoint, and some other quirks, Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is essentially a Legend of Zelda style game inside. But why is this a bad thing? As a diehard Zelda fan, I welcome the gaming industry to create their own attempts at Zelda-like games, whether from AAA developers or indies. And Oceanhorn does a fine job of being a fun game, even though almost all of its major elements are pretty much lifted from the Zelda series. But let's be fair here, bows, bombs, swords, shields, and sailing are far from monopolized by Zelda.

Getting into Oceanhorn itself, there's a lot to like about this game. The art style has its own charm, the isometric viewpoint is neat and a nice callback to games like Mario RPG and Landstalker, and the music... sublime. It all comes together in a wonderful presentation package that should delight anyone who can see past the game's obvious inspiration. The controls, for the most part, are pretty fluid, especially considering this is a port of an iOS game, and it felt just right on a controller, although the main character does move just the smallest bit slower than I'd like him to. The sailing atmosphere is gorgeous, and it's fun visiting new islands and charting them out, learning what secrets and people dwell there. The puzzles, while not entirely brainteasers, were the right amount of clever and made the game feel fluid. Dungeons are clever and designed expertly, with creative boss fights I quite enjoyed. In some ways it's a bit on the easy end, but no easier than your typical Zelda game.

The cons with this game are minor. There's the often-cited lack of a map screen, which would have been very handy. I find it odd that you can't dash or roll up steps, which would be nice for speeding up action. And the sailing is even more restrictive than that of Phantom Hourglass; in that game you could at least plot a course, but here, you can only select a destination. I would have liked a little more control, especially in that gorgeous atmosphere, but it's a minor concern.

Also, the game is too short. :(

But that's both a pro and a con; a con, because the game did feel a bit on the shorter side, and a pro, because I only wanted more.

In short, Oceanhorn is worth it if you're a fan of adventure games, especially Zelda obviously, whose only shortcomings are minor. Hopefully the game becomes successful enough to warrant a sequel in the future. Great product, Cornfox & Brothers, and may you see continued success!

reviewText:
Videogames are in love with themselves. Or rather, they’re in love with the monoliths of gaming history, the games that for many form a mesh of absolutes and ideals which other games continually seek to emulate. Sometimes this leads to the betterment of an idea, a concept first imitated and then refined so that it then becomes synonymous with this new game that did it better. Other times though the ways games so constantly seek to recreate their predecessors never extends beyond rudimentary or reductive replication, seeking success by playing to familiarity and nostalgia. This is where we are met with Oceanhorn: Monster of the Uncharted Seas, a would be Zelda clone that is the gaming equivalent to that off-brand action figure your grandmother mistakenly bought you for Christmas, on the surface indistinguishable from the original but whose inadequacy becomes immediately known once the disingenuous packaging is breached.

Oceanhorn mirrors not only Zelda’s style of play, but its aesthetic and structure. Its art design is inarguably seeking to reflect that of Zelda’s more cartoony iterations, specifically the nautically inclined Wind Waker and Phantom Hourglass. Oceanhorn’s world is bright and colorful, segmented into different islands you access by sailing on those supposedly uncharted seas, with a bouncy demeanor that is unable to distract from the overwhelming feeling of artificiality present in every aspect of Oceanhorn’s design. This isn’t wholly due to Oceanhorn’s status as a poor man’s Zelda, but the result of a world that feels entirely synthetic. The whimsical charm and history always so paramount to Zelda’s world design is entirely absent, replaced with a cold and alienating feeling of obligation. Oceanhorn’s world exists entirely for the sake of housing its plot, a plot which expands and shrinks in whichever way it finds convenient, pouring out backstory when it needs to feel grandiose and then receding into the background when it fails to back up its attempts at magnificence with anything more than words.

Where Zelda constructs its narrative to intersect and enhance its mechanics, Oceanhorn uses it as a crux. Things happen because the game needs you to move to the next dungeon. Plot is only ever employed for the sake of giving context to your actions, but the writing is so stale and inconsistent that it causes the game as a whole to feel even more so the product of recognizable but unofficial parts. Details are always given in terms meant to imply a storied history to this land, with caves and lost princesses being hidden away for thousands of years, and yet within minutes of arriving to these areas you are able to overcome whatever obstacle was standing in the way of the local inhabitants, often by such trivial means as to call into question whether anyone has actually cared even a little about the fate of their world until you arrived. There is an astounding level of pointlessness to Oceanhorn’s plot given how much time it dedicates to selling you on it, to the point I feel it would be better off simply tearing it all out and letting the mechanics speak for themselves.

It seems fair to say Oceanhorn’s main draw isn’t its plot but its mechanical similarity to Zelda, so its true test is in how well it manages to reconstruct a formula that has changed little over the years and yet remains incredibly well regarded and popular. In this Oceanhorn is…fine. It manages to mirror many of Zelda’s most recognizable aspects, from item based navigation puzzles to dungeon layouts and boss designs, but it never loses that feeling of being a cheap imitation. One of Zelda’s biggest strengths is in the multilayered design of its world and dungeons, where puzzles build upon themselves as your means of solving them becomes larger, each knew item bringing with it a host of immediate and secondary applications.

Oceanhorn in comparison is much less intricate in its design, presenting you with new items when it sees fit but never giving you much to do with them. There are puzzles here they are more like speedbumps than roadblocks, tending to hold you up for a moment but ultimately tedious to overcome and often of the same block-pushing variety. The lack of intelligent level and puzzle designs causes Oceanhorn to feel intensely segmented and linear, each dungeon serving to send you on the next but having little for you to actually do while you’re there. Exploration is nearly entirely absent both within levels and in the overworld, the former due to the narrow design of each island, and the later as the boat you use to travel between islands is entirely on rails.

Even as one of the few who enjoyed Wind Waker’s sailing, traveling between islands in Oceanhorn is excruciatingly obnoxious. There is so little to do in these segments that their inclusion is as worthless as the plot attempting to justify it. The ocean itself is tepid and lifeless and the only thing populating it an abundance of trash you need to clear away with your cannon, a task no doubt meant to keep you occupied until you arrive at your destination but only serving to make sailing even more annoying as you are then required to pay attention the whole time you are cruising along lest you bump into a mine someone carelessly left floating around. The monotony of sailing caused me to lose any interest I might have had to return to previous island to pick up a collectible I missed or finish up some of the sidequest objectives I hadn’t gotten around to, though these additions contribute so little to the game that the only real reason to pursue them is for the sake of completion.

Oceanhorn’s only truly alluring aspect is its novelty as the closest PC and mobile players can get to a native Zelda game. With so little like it on these platforms it is tempting to accept and justify Oceanhorn’s middling to bad attempts to replicate Nintendo’s iconic franchise, solely because it’s all we are likely to ever get. But for as hard as it might try, there is no mistaking Oceanhorn as anything but a knock-off, and not a good one at that. Its design is uninspired and meandering, a chore to navigate and a bore to solve. Even excluding comparisons to Zelda proper, Oceanhorn isn’t fun to play, and if it wasn’t for bearing such a striking resemblance to that series I doubt anyone would have paid it much attention in the first place.

I will be judging Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas on its own and not as a part of the The Legend of Zelda (LOZ) series. Summary
Just let me get this out of the way first: The price is way off. 14,99€ is a fantastic deal, if we are talking about one of the main portable LOZ games like Link's Awakening or Spirit Tracks, but this is a simpler, less polished product and should have a lower price; something like 7,99€ would make more sense, so I would definitely wait for a sale or a bundle to get this.

Oceanhorn is an action/adventure game à la LOZ, a top-down game with a large focus on exploration and puzzles, but with a fair amount of combat as well. The combat is as you would expect: You swing the sword with one button and hold it for a charged spin attack. What you might not expect coming from LOZ is the stamina bar. In this case, it is used to do a quick, short dash, to block with your shield and to roll/jump (item required). The combat is further improved by the use of the 5 spells. These tend to often (but not always) be neglected in the LOZ series, and I am glad that it is not the case here. Oceanhorn is also very generous with item drops, perhaps a bit too generous, as you can often kill an enemy with a bomb, and then just get the bomb back; freeze and one-shot an enemy, only to get your magic back et cetera.

When it comes to exploration, Oceanhorn provides similar block- and environment-based puzzles to the LOZ games. These often require the use of the items/spells you collect during the game; they are usually fairly easy, maybe because of the limited item/spell pool, maybe because of design choices, but some of them can provide at least a bit of a challenge; you do not just rush through them, at any rate. The game is rather short, with 3 main dungeons, but a lot of optional areas and collectibles for you to spend your time with. The main problems are related to the narrative, and I, being a mostly gameplay-centered person, do not really care much about that anyway, but I will cover it in the next paragraph, because it is still a weak part of the game, even when compared to LOZ, which is not a series known for its strong and original plots.

reviewText:
***Disclosure: Key was provided by the developer for review purposes***

It's basically a Zelda-clone. And it really doesn't hide that fact at all. One of the very first things you encounter are pots you can pick up and throw in order to destroy them. There are bushes you can cut down with your sword in order to collect money, bombs and arrows and you have to explore dungeons in order to collect three pieces of a mystical item that helps you defeat the final boss. You also get a new, stronger sword and a new shield over the course of the game. The only thing it doesn't directly lift form Zelda games is the fact that there isn't a princess in this. Otherwise it's an extremely faithful homage to Link's adventures, especially Wind Waker and Phantom Hourglass, since it incorporates a lot of sailing as well.

I think the most interesting aspect about the game is the fact that it actually came out on mobile devices first. Because while playing it on PC, I honestly wouldn't have guessed its origins. The interface is perfectly adapted for PC and it's playable with both controller and mouse and keyboard. And for a mobile game it's definitely quite a lengthy game to play. It took me on PC around 10 hours to get through and I haven't even collected all the hidden secrets in there and even for a proper PC game the length is adequate enough. The only thing it's lacking is good bossfights. There are only really six bossfights and two of those don't involve any strategies beyond holding up your shield and countering when the enemy is exposing himself. Three of the boss fights are the ones where you collect the faux-Triforce shards and then the last one at the very end. Even though you need to employ different tactics to beat them, they're not all that challenging to figure out.

And since there's only three shards to collect, there are only really three big dungeons to explore. The other dungeons are very small and don't contain many puzzles. And speaking of the puzzles, they're mostly very easy block pushing or switch pressing puzzles. Only one of the puzzles was rather hard for me to guess, the rest is fairly straightforward.

Other than that I can say that I'm very pleased with the art style. They really managed to capture the typical whimsical Zelda aesthetic. Though what elevates the experience is definitely the soundtrack. It does take a lot of inspiration from other video game composers, but it's still very enjoyable and very fitting to all your surroundings.

If there's one problem I had, at least with the beta build I got for review purposes, it's the amount of crashes I suffered. The game constantly crashed on me for no apparent reason, and it had tremendous difficulty maintaining 60 FPS on my rig which is saying a lot. Though I did notice that the crashes subsided on the day prior to release, so maybe they've fixed it. Though really, the crashes were only annoying in the sense that I had to restart the game. Because the auto-save function is pretty damn awesome in this game, I barely lost any progress while playing it, so there's that at least.

In the end, it's an obvious Zelda-clone because that's exactly what it wants to be. And for an effort from a small indie studio form Finland it's definitely not a bad one. It obviously can't hold a candle to a proper Zelda-game, but keep in mind that they're created by an army of programmers, artists and composers who basically swim in Nintendo-money.

In Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas you start your gameplay as a young man who wakes up to find his father gone; he disappeared after going in search of a monster known as Oceanhorn. With only your father's notebook and your mother's mysterious necklace as clues, you set off in his search and thus begins the adventure.

Oceanhorn is a very nice casual action/adventure RPG, complete with puzzles, which is quite reminiscent in many ways to Legend of Zelda. The gameplay revolves around you finding clues from NPCs, battling monsters, solving puzzles and collecting keys and treasures from the different islands around the vast world while you search for your father and discover more to the story and lore of the place. The story and lore might not be too in-depth, but it's deep enough to keep you going through the game.

As I understand it this game was first made for iOS and then ported to PC, and although the port and game play are smooth enough that you might not have realized it, you can tell it was meant to be mobile by the way certain things work - such as in moving the world map, sliding the menu and other specific touch screen features.

Although the developers lean to the simplistic side, the game's graphics are beautiful: bright, colorful, and they feel quite alive. There is something definitely cute about all the characters you encounter and the sights are gorgeous. The way all islands are a bit different, each with their own little biome, some even with weather, adds interest to the gameplay and makes visiting each one a slightly unique experience. This spontaneous element helps keep it from being tedious.

The music was also wonderful, fitting to the world and the islands. The voice acting was a bit hit and miss, but for the most it was pretty good. I just wish the main character would have spoken, too.

The camera I found a bit annoying at first, as it's not free roam; you can only move it a little bit left and right, but I got used to it quickly and it did not hinder my enjoyment in the end. The camera follows you during boss battles too, which was both extremely helpful (as it did not get in my way), and extremely dizzying when my main strategy was “back up in circles and wait for an opening”.

reviewText:
Being an Android user, this came out of the blue for me. As a huge fan of the Legend of Zelda, and Zelda-likes, this is very much welcomed to my library.

The visual aesthetic is pretty much Wind Waker, with a touch of Minecraft inspired cubic layouts.

Gameplay wise, there is a very simple two button combat system. Your input options change dynamically as you approach objects you can interact with, which can work very well. Managing items is simple and forgiving; you're given more inputs for quick access than I've seen in most Zelda titles.

While the puzzles are mostly tried and true block and button puzzles, its a great trip back to nostalgia lane and leaves me wanting more modern releases from this genre.

Unlike other games of it's genre, there's a levelling system to Oceanhorn. Your character gains experiences through defeating monsters and completing specific goals. Then, through the adventurers guild, you are given access to different weapons and features in the game. This is a great way to tie progress to your regular combat and accomplishments throughout the game.

Cornfox and Bros have done a convincing and enjoyable unique recreation of the travel based Zeldas. I'm a huge fan of this so far, and I can't wait to see what else it has to offer.

reviewText:
This game totally caught me by surprise. It's an incredibly well done Zelda clone(circa Link to the Past) with a healthy dose of the elevation-based problem solving from the classic Genesis adventure Landstalker. The game takes all it can from Zelda right down to the pieces of heart collectibles and block pushing puzzles to the simplistic but effective hack and slash combat. Heck, even the world map is itself a total Windwaker copycat(however nowhere near as tedious or annoying).

It adds it's own features here and there such as a leveling system, quests and a tad more open exploration than certain Zelda titles, and a more involved story but it's part and parcel a huge homage to the trend setting franchise. In no way is that a knock to the game's character because it's all done nearly as well as an indie dev could do so.

The music is another feature that struck me as well. It's another high quality aspect of an already high quality product, even if it sounds slightly Zelda-ish at times (when you first leave your house, you'll instantly get the feeling you've been here before).

If you're someone who loves Zelda or hack and slash adventures in general, you can't go wrong with picking this game up. It would seem so far that it's going to be at least a solid 20-30 hours to fully complete also, possibly more so it's totally worth the price for a game that even begins to touch the greatness that is Zelda.

reviewText:
“Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas” is an interesting game in concept. It accurately compares itself to the “Legend of Zelda” titles and is definitely reminiscent of the core gameplay in that series. The interesting part however comes from the game being on mobile devices and PC, whereas Nintendo has so far only released Zelda games on their own consoles. “Oceanhorn” attempts to tap into a niche, and does it fairly well, despite lacking the polish that Nintendo fans have come to expect.

The game is a mostly isometric dungeon crawler game akin to Zelda games. Using a sword and shield, along with various items unlocked through the game, the goal is to progress through various dungeons and reach the boss of each area. At times this is much easier said than done, as the level layouts can be a bit confusing at times. The levels themselves however look fantastic, and generally speaking the game’s graphical quality is up to the standard of the Zelda games, just with a bit less bloom which is very welcome.

In fairness to the game, as of yet I haven’t run into any major issues that have stopped me from progressing or caused me to wonder what exactly the developer was thinking, however my problems with the game arise from a series of small things that are missing. The easiest way to describe it is unfortunately just to reiterate the first paragraph; the game lacks polish in many areas.

The graphics of the game, as previously mentioned are pretty great, the game genuinely looks gorgeous, especially the water used to sail between islands. However some texture glitches and clipping can stand out while trying to solve a puzzle, and the isometric viewpoint can be a bit of a problem at times even with an adjustable camera. The game’s combat is generally solid, however hitbox issues can make fighting a bit unsatisfying, and the music sits comfortably in between being great and defining the landscape as Zelda games use their soundtrack, and being fairly mediocre. I never found reason to complain, but unlike some other games in recent memory, it never left me wanting a soundtrack to slap on my phone.

However, a lot of the issues I’ve raised with this game are present in others like it, and are usually forgivable, however for something that compares itself to a Zelda game, it’s hard to not judge it in the same vein as those titles. That said, this review has been a bit harsh so far -- while the game definitely lacks the polish of Zelda titles, it brings some of its own traits to the table which add to the game.

An experience system and a sprint function without having to wait to unlock the Pegasus Boots is likely the biggest improvement, as being able to zip around places you’ve already been through means hopping right back into a dungeon is always just a couple seconds away. The challenges offer experience as a reward and can add some interesting depth to the game, assuming it’s not a simple one like breaking several pots, something Zelda fans were going to do anyway.

Overall, the game does a decent job at mimicking the Zelda series, but as stated before multiple times, the lack of polish can stand out and may put some people off from the title. That’s unfortunate, because the game is generally enjoyable. It makes some legitimate improvements to the formula of Zelda titles, it’s just hard to not look at some aspects of the game and wish the developers had a bit more experience behind them so they could smooth out the rough bits. That said, it’s an enjoyable experience that at the least attempts to shake things up a bit.

3/5

reviewText:
The Good:
- Art design and music lend perfectly to the genre. The game obviously emulates Zelda, but it also reminds me of other classics like Landstalker (Genesis) and Alundra (PS1).  If you’re into these types of games, you’ll definitely enjoy what Oceanhorn has to offer.

- Certainly, the upgrades and variety of gadgets could have been more robust and there could have been more towns to explore, but as a five hour experience (if you're just focused on the main story), Oceanhorn didn’t need these extra elements to be enjoyable.

- Unlike other reviewers, I really liked the sailing segments. It’s essentially an on-rails shooting gallery that gives the player an opportunity to refill their inventory and health before reaching a new island.

The Bad:
- For the most part, Oceanhorn ran smoothly; however, there were a few times during my play through that the frame rate plummeted. This occurred mostly when entering the towns, but thankfully it only lasted for ten to twenty seconds before returning back to normal speed.

- This game desperately needed an active mission hint system to give the player suggestions on where to go or how to accomplish certain goals. For me, this would have been helpful after major segments of the game as it took a bit of trial and error to figure out where to go next.

- Boss fights ranged from tedious to overly convoluted.

- If you’re an achievement hunter this game is not hard to fully complete. But, some of the fishing challenges (The Botfish) were ridiculously frustrating.

Final Verdict:
I recommend this game, but only if it’s on sale. While there are numerous positives to Oceanhorn, there are design and game play elements which unquestionably detract from the overall enjoyment of the game.

reviewText:
This is poorly written love letter to the Zelda series.  The games takes all the best pieces from our favorite Zelda games and alters them just enough to make the game both nostalgic and fun, yet unneccessarily frustrating.

The first noticible difference is the graphical style of this game, which looks to be tiered.  By that I mean it is made out of blocks or little plateaus.  These plateaus can present neat exploration challenges, because the player needs to access and fall from them to get bonus items.  But, the player cannot rotate the camera around them.  Yes, there is a little wiggle room with the camera, but it's pretty static.  This presents problems when an enemy is behind one of these plateaus.

The next major problem with the game is level design, which is compounded by these plateaus.  The game has a constant mini-map up in the lower right corner of the screen, but when moving through box-maze after box-maze, it's useless.  The player will ultimately find it easier to simply memorize his path than use the mini map.  Levels and dungeons also become frustrating because navigating through them becomes cumbersome, since they are made up of plateaus and no camera.  Furthermore, they can become just downright confusing.  There are too many branches which just lead the player around in circles and never really direct the player on a path.

This brings up the general pacing of the game.  Like Windwaker, the games is broken up into tons of small islands.  But it is never clear where to go.  When the player first leaves the tutorial island and makes it to a town, a sign-post says to explore each new island as the player learns about them!  Good advice.  Except, when exploring the town island, the player is given the location of no less than three new islands to explore!  Two out of three of them are dead ends until you choose to explore the correct island and get necessary items.  This was just poorly designed.

That said, this is a game has its own identity.  The combat feels different than Zelda games, and although not wildly different, it's enough to make it stand on its own.  The shield should always be up, and hits eat away at a stamina bar which replenishes when down or not in combat, similar to Dark Souls, although that's the only comparison I can make.

The graphics are different from other Zelda titles, and I find them to be pleasant.  The zones, however, were just such rip-offs from Zelda that I found it a bit distracting at times.  Ultimately, however, I tended to look at the game as it's own game rather than a copy.  Superfans of Zelda might not be able to do that.

Ultimately, if you were a fan of the SNES Zelda and Gamecube/Wii-U Windwaker, this game should hit a nostalgic high point for you.  It's got most of the great elements of those two games, but just bundled in a sub-par game-pace and level-design.

Overall, I'd recommend it with the caveats I've mentioned, especially since it is cheap.  It's aggravating, but it's bold in how it takes on a giant and tries to take on the juggernaut.  It'll certainly strike a nerve with the 30-somthing crowd.

6.5/10 - Thoroughly forgettable

The line above sums up the entire experience, sadly.
Oceanhorn is a really nicely presented game - the colourful, stylized graphics and really pleasant music are a highlight in the category of presentation - that brings the Zelda-like style of gameplay to PCs, but is nowhere near good enough to live to the reputation of aforementioned Zelda games. What we get instead is a stroll through several islands, hunt for collectibles and a story that barely does anything.

Let's start with the last on that list - while not overly complicated, and often obvious with its revelations/suggestions, the story of the game seems like an excuse thrown together without much thinking. The motivations and some connections are very sketchy, to the point where they don't get any explanation at all. Add to the fact that there is no real closure, the start and the end of the story feel almost random and... you have something that lives in the background, but that's about it. The big discrepancies in the performance of voice actors don't help - some of them sound like they just couldn't care for a single moment.
Unless we count shoe-horned insinuations of romantic interest and the like, which were as unnecessary and clunkily handed as possible.

Collectible hunt is actually fun, if you are after completing your games 100%, then this is a thing for you. There is plenty of exploring, bombing, jumping and otherwise figuring out how to get to that elusive last blood gem or chest. Coupled with the fact that the labyrinthine, complicated structure of the islands makes it interesting to poke your nose in every corner - it works well.
Which can't be exactly said about the puzzles, as they are divided into two categories, as far as I am concerned - relatively easy ones and those you will frown at because they are timed. Why would the latter be a problem? Because of how some of the control scheme works. The biggest offender here are Trencher Boots. For reasons I cannot fathom, aside from their primary function of jumping gaps (Zelda's ladder basically) they also have a roll function, which doubles the role of the dash the character has from the very beginning. Now, this roll can cause you to fall down from low-height platforms when you would rather jump from one to another, because both of these functions are tied to one button and which goes off is dependant on your position. And when you have a timed puzzle, you want to cut corners.
There are several more control gripes like that - throwing objects can be finicky, sword combat doesn't feel all too nice either. Bow has the same issues as throwing object which means... you will be okay, but sometimes it takes a wild guess whether you can hit something at all, and times when you will waste three arrows because you weren't just precise enough with turning your character around will happen.

All the issues and positives combined, Oceanhorn is... okay. You will probably enjoy yourself, spend 10-20 hours in it, then put back onto the virtual shelf. And forget about it, because what this game lacks the most, is anything that would make it leave a mark on your memories.
I would gladly give this game a neutral review if I could, but as it stands, a thumbs down is in order. Because the game isn't bad, but it is not worth recommending either.

reviewText:
The short of it is that if you greatly enjoyed The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker(or games like it), and you have a ton of free time on your hands, than you should give this game a chance. Otherwise, if you didn't, don't have that much time, or have access to Wind Waker, than you are better off skipping this game (and just playing Wind Waker instead).

The long of it is that this game is a mediocre adventure game with some charming elements to it, but lacks polish. Which is very disappointing since it is easy to see how this game could have been much better, had they just done a little bit more.  The lack of polish in this game is shown in nearly every part of it, but the two that I think best display it are these.

First, the game has a problem with visual cues, or to be more exact, it sometimes doesn't display any, or displays the wrong ones.  This happens at several places throughout the game, for example, sometimes there are floor tiles in a object moving puzzle section that will use the same texture as the border tiles, even though, you can slide things onto them. Not only is this confusing, but it is also very frustrating, since the solution ends up being very simple.  This visual inconsistence is bizarre, since at times it seems like it was done intentional. Like they wonder why no one else does this kind of thing (using the same texture for both a valid and invalid movement space) before, and they figure that they would.  Also, there a part in the game where the player run across a spiked gate. Not only does this looks goofy, but it doesn't make sense, since throughout the game spikes are used as a hazard.  Except in this one case, where it is the intended path.  These visual cue issues don't break the game, but they do happen enough to be a problem, which is disappointing, since they seem like they would be easy to fix.

Second, most of the game's puzzles, aren't challenging and feel meaningless, since they are just one step. For example, some time you'll run into a barred gateway, and to get past this gateway, all you have to do is use a switch. And most of the time the switch itself is within 20 feet of the gateway with nothing blocking you from using it. Other times you'll run into a pathway that splits into 2. Down one path is a locked door, and down the other is the key for that locked door. It is this simplistic design that makes most of the game's content feel shallow. There are no a-ha moments, no sense of achievement, and really nothing remarkable about running into a puzzle and then spending 5 seconds to get through it. In the end it feels like they have all the pieces that are used to make a puzzle, but missed the point of why gamers like to solve them.

Overall Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a mediocre adventure game. It can be fun at times, but it usually isn't. The game has a decent foundation, but it execution of those ideas is lacking.  The game as is, isn't worth it, but I found its potential to be interesting.

reviewText:
Blah blah Zelda Blah Blah

Oceanhorn takes place in an archipelago inhabited by several sentient races. From fish dudes to eagle people. From several types of humans to even machines. Also the occasional demon. There's also ghosts in the postgame dungeon. Like all video games, it starts out peacefully but everything turns to hell and some random kid with a destiny has to save the world. To do that, you hunt an ancient relic from the technologically advanced past named Oceanhorn but there's a twist...which I'll save for those who play the game.

The main character is the aptly named Main Character (or Hero). At the start of the game, his father writes a note saying how his (the father's) destiny is linked to Oceanhorn, which also means the Hero's destiny is too because that's how video games work). He then goes to attack a giant robotic crab. The Hero then wakes up on a different island inhabited by one guy named Hermit who sends you on your way to avenge your father and save the world. All the while a Black Boat stalks you from just off screen except when plot demands otherwise.

The game then continues like all action games: you visit scenic locals; a desert, a dense forest, some ruins, a quaint little town, a floating rock, etc. and you upgrade your gear, learn to use magic, and learn just how special you are because your parents are doubly special. Once in a while, you fish or throw plants at the head of their gardener/Hero's love interest because you (as the player) are a sociopath.

The controls are exceptional for a game that was originally an iOS game – at least with an X-box controller. The only issue that can, and totally will, happen is how easy it is to fall off a ledge and have to redo entire sections of dungeons again. It's not game breaking but it can be annoying having to back track several screens because you were pushed off a small walkway or you just got to close to pick something up or to avoid another thing. It's great that being able to jump down ledges is a thing – it allows for a bit of a different type of exploration – but it's frustrating to no end when you've done it too many times. Other than that, combat is fairly fluid. Arrows and magic go where you send them and there are never too many enemies on screen to make one have to panic. The puzzle aspects don't interfere with combat when they're intermingled (meaning boss battles).

Sadly, the plot isn't all there. I'm not saying there are any plotholes but some of it just feels rushed and just didn't feel deep to me. A random girl suddenly being your love interest is the most obvious one. It's not a main plot in the story so it might just be something that bothered me slightly and you might be totally fine with it. The game is all narrative which, is fine, but it's easy to miss things or important information can be easily forgetten. For example, if you don't talk to the correct people or find certain bottles then certain side quests aren't going to be available to you. Nothing story related is missable but you might not get to full health, arrow/bomb capacity, or challenge completion (if you're into that though, you're probably using a guide). The game keeps going after you beat the main boss so even then, you can go back and find what you want to. Nothing is permanently missable. Some of this might just be mobile limitations that unfortunately show in this PC port. I don't do a lot of mobile gaming so I'm not sure what is and what isn't great.

Music is a very subjective subject but I can say that I found it to be perfect. It fits the mood and helps provide immersion. Nobuo Uematsu wrote a track for the OST so that's all you really need to know. I like to add official sources where one can preview it so here's a link.
Youtube

This is Cornfox & Bros first RPG (and second game after a top-down Carmageddon/Twisted Metal style remake – Death Rally) and these Finnish developers already have my attention. I'm looking forward to anything they might release in the future. Zelda games don't come out very often so go pick this up if you're feeling a lull or just want a short, fun adventure. $15 might be a little too steep for some but remember, holidays and summers are always just around the corner.

reviewText:
Presentation
The premise behind Oceanhorn's story is something you have probably seen a hundred times before, as the story kicks off with the hero's father leaving to save the world, only to put you in control of the hero with a quest to find your father and help him defeat Oceanhorn moments after. From there onward you'll experience an entire Zelda-like adventure, looking for the location and a way to defeat Oceanhorn and rescue your father. There is always something new to discover, but Oceanhorn's biggest miss is when you realize that all your discovery excitement that builds up as you move forward quickly goes back to zero once you realize that there are few things to experience besides the main story. There are sixteen different islands to visit, mostly serving as an essential part to the storyline, but only a few of those have gameplay value to encourage a full exploration such as Tikarel which serves as the main town where you can buy items and take on new quests. Unfortunately, the rest of many are only a one-time visit deal, as you can finish everything there is to see and experience in less than 15 minutes and never return to that island again. There are some activities such as finishing and completing the different challenges that might add a bit of variety, but even those feel repetitive and pretty basic to any RPG. The story itself has nothing much to offer as you can probably guess how it's all going to end from the very beginning, but nevertheless, the journey all the way to the final island is an enjoyable ride if you're willing to look past the repetitiveness and basic concepts.
Rating: 7.5

Gameplay
Not only does Oceanhorn feel like a Zelda game, but it plays like one too; if you have played a Zelda game before the formula will seem very familiar to you: make your way to that dungeon, defeat the boss in order to obtain the item you need, return to town to gather more information about your next quest and repeat until you get to the end. Navigation is done via a Wind Waker-like boat mechanic that allows you to travel from one island to the next one using your boat, but there are very few things to do on sea, as the only thing to keep you preoccupied while you reach your next destination are the barrels and mines that randomly pop in front of you as you sail, but after a while, even those start to become more annoying than fun, as the whole concept becomes repetitive and unrewarding. On land, the gameplay is pretty basic, as you only have a few spells at your disposal and your sword attacks, but once you realize that some spells are only useful once for the boss battle that they were designed for, the whole adventure will only become more and more repetitive. There are only a few enemies that you will encounter throughout your adventures, most of which can be defeated with basic sword attacks that require no strategy at all, while the boss battles vary in quality, as some of them feel intelligent and rewarding, while others are just a very long game of poke-poke-hit. Apart from the main quest itself, there are few things to keep you occupied in your adventures and while locating all of the bloodstones feels rewarding in the end, that reward will probably come in too late as you would've already finished the game by then.
Rating: 7

Graphics

Navigation is done via a Wind Waker-like boat mechanic that allows you to travel from one island to the next one using your boat, but there are very few things to do on sea, as the only thing to keep you preoccupied while you reach your next destination are the barrels and mines that randomly pop in front of you as you sail, but after a while, even those start to become more annoying than fun, as the whole concept becomes repetitive and unrewarding. On land, the gameplay is pretty basic, as you only have a few spells at your disposal and your sword attacks, but once you realize that some spells are only useful once for the boss battle that they were designed for, the whole adventure will only become more and more repetitive. There are only a few enemies that you will encounter throughout your adventures, most of which can be defeated with basic sword attacks that require no strategy at all, while the boss battles vary in quality, as some of them feel intelligent and rewarding, while others are just a very long game of poke-poke-hit. Apart from the main quest itself, there are few things to keep you occupied in your adventures and while locating all of the bloodstones feels rewarding in the end, that reward will probably come in too late as you would've already finished the game by then.
Rating: 6.5

Audio
There are some great tunes in here, and if you didn't know different you could say there were in the soundtrack of a Zelda game, but they do start repeating after a while and it does make it boring listening to the same thing all over again. The effects are enough to justify the means, but the voice acting is absent, not that the game would necessarily need it since the quests instructions are pretty clearly delivered via text dialogue, but it would've been nice to have that option, at least for the main cutscenes to make the whole missing father story more personal.
Rating: 7.5

Extras
You can finish the whole game within 10 hours, add a few more if you're willing to revisit every island in order to gather all the bloodstones and complete all the challenges, but that's pretty much all of it, and since some skills are required to access a few areas, you can't complete everything in your visit visit, so you will have to deal with the repetitiveness of the main story first and then move on to the repetitiveness of the sidequests.
Rating: 7

Verdict
It's impossible to deny the fact that Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas is a Zelda clone since it feels, plays and looks like a game in the Zelda series, but it's a pretty decent one, so if you liked Zelda and want more of it, Oceanhorn might prove to be an entertaining adventure for you. The game does come with its flaws and lack of content, but in the end it will prove out to be an adventure worth playing.

Puzzles involving hitting switches, pushing boxes, and pressure plates? ✔
Smashing ceramics and chopping grass for money? ✔
Bosses with titles? ✔
Copyright infringement? ✔

Imitation really is the best form of flattery. If you're a Zelda fan who's thirsty for adventure, look no further. For a port of a mobile game, Oceanhorn manages to look pretty. The visuals have been polished and everything looks shiny and new, but there are some framerate problems. The art style is pretty much ripped from The Wind Waker, so fans should feel right at home. Speaking of The Wind Waker, you get a boat! This is how you travel from island to island. Unfortunately, your boat doesn't talk and you can't steer it yourself. Traveling between islands is an on-rails affair, but there are enemies to keep you on your toes and driftwood to be smashed for the loot it contains. There's also a leveling system that basically replaces bigger quivers and bomb bags from the Zelda franchise. You gain experience from slaying baddies and attaining in-game achievements, which can force you to backtrack but do add to the longetivity of your adventure. Puzzles are a bit on the easy side and some items are a bit too familiar, but why fix gameplay that isn't broken? If you're a Zelda fan, Oceanhorn is a must-have for your Steam library.

+ Gameplay is immediately familiar
+ Environments are lovely, varied, and don't overstay their welcome
+ Great soundtrack

- Framerate issues
- Controls could be tighter
- Not being able to sail the ocean yourself is a bit of a bummer

reviewText:
This game is a zelda-clone, in particular a windwaker/phantom hourglass clone. However, it's a much shorter and smaller game. The gameplay and graphics are pretty decent, but the story, characters, and puzzles are relatively lackluster. Some of my favorite things about windwaker were the large, mostly open world to explore, the quirky characters and their accompanying side-quests, and the variety of items to use. However, those aspects were not really present in this game.

The sailing in this game is very boring to me. You're on a track to whichever island you choose as your destination and then there are a few obstacles you get to shoot in the 30 seconds or less it takes you to get to another island. No sunken treasures, outposts, or islands to discover(you just hear about them from other people and then go from point A to point B). The characters are not terribly memorable at all, although I did enjoy the designs of the rito and zora clones (owlbros and gillfolk). The only real items you get are bombs, arrows, and the ability to jump. There is also magic, but I think it could've been used more for the puzzles and bosses. You get this super cool black hole spell if you get a certain number of bloodstones and it's not effective against bosses and isn't nearly as cool as the name implies.  The story is about as cliche as it gets, but this time you're helping your dad instead of a princess.

That said, the quality is really nice for an indie game. The music is solid, but falls short of the glory of zelda soundtracks. The art is pretty and while the environments are blocky like in phantom hourglass, they're still made to look relatively natural. The combat works nicely and there are a fair number of enemies that you can't mindlessly hack and slash without first getting behind them or breaking their guard somehow. I also liked the fishing minigame.

I'd recommend this for people who really like Zelda games, but expect a game about a third (or less) as long and half as good.

7/10

This is a barely playable homage to 3D zelda that badly ports 2D zelda mechanics to mouse and keyboard.

It's inconsistent about the controls, equating clicking in certain spots to pressing spacebar, but only in certain contexts.  It's inconsistent about it's geometry, having the character sometimes but not always be able to jump off edges or climb, depending on what the game feels like allowing without any visual indicators.

The game starts off with a boring cutscene monologuing about some mysterious monster that an NPC has to go fight voiced by character that isn't there yet (reused voices?), before a voice that is never even given a character tell you to wake up.  With that backstory, the game hands you a list of controls and a list of achievements as your primary motivation for doing things.  From there the game assume the player will get the hidden chest nearby and only then explains why it was significant, while still refusing to give any in-game motivations, and even contradicting its own setting.  The mc was not supposed to get the sword and shield, despite living on a tiny island with monsters alongside an old man who can't defend himself?  I call BS.

And then the sailing section occurs.  The game gives no indication of how sailing works.  I won't hide it.  I stopped playing here, because I couldn't convince the game to do anything.  Even after I looked on the forums, all I could find was a tip saying to click a couple hundred times and it'll work.

If anyone tells you this game is like zelda or the closest to zelda you'll get on PC, ignore them, and go look up Ittle Dew.  It's an actually playable game that pays homage to zelda.

Overview: Isometric RPG
Similar Games: Legend of Zelda

The Good:

+ The artwork looks great

+ Game controls really well

+ Killing enemies and completed challenges rewards you with experience giving you some upgrades per level increase.

+ Music and sound effects

The Bad:

-The game's biggest flaw is the level design. Every 'island' you visit is one large complex, confusing puzzle that looks and feels the same in every regard. The puzzles are not nearly as well design as its counterpart that it's trying to rip-off and halfway through the game it starts feeling like a chore rather than fun.

- Selecting an island to travel, has you sailing in a ship that looks eerily similar to that in Legend of Zelda Wind waker. However you don't actually control the ship, the game does that for you while you shoot from a canon, destroying the same enemies over and over again. It was fun in the beginning but like the rest of the game it starts to feel derivative after a while.

- Story and characters feel very uninspired.

- Boss Battles are boring and frustrating to play.


Conclusion.

Oceanhorn is HEAVILY inspired from the legend of zelda series, and while that may be a good idea the game fails in its execution. If Steam had a 'meh' option I would probably choose that. Sadly I will give this game a negative review, because although the game is certainly competent in certain regards the fact that it tries so hard to be like Legend of Zelda and misses the mark is what really hurts it at the end.

I have no idea why anyone would recommend this game to people who like the Zelda games. Why would you want to play an inferior version of Zelda? Because that's essentially what this is, a bad version of Zelda. I love the design, and the atmosphere is cool, but other than this game is pretty mediocre. The camera is locked, you're kind of weak (I haven't gotten the Coral Sabre yet, however), the stamina system stinks (although it does make sense, it just hampers the game, it doesn't add anything), your ammunition is super low until you hit the max level (where you can hold 99 bombs and 99 arrows), the monsters drop far too little money and experience, the items lack originality, the puzzles aren't that creative.

The one thing I think the developers did well is the drop rate, which is very high, so your low amount of maximum ammunition doesn't severely hamper you as it's pretty easy to fill your bomb bag and quiver up. The ship travels quickly from island to island as well, so that's another good point. So yeah, if you've never played a Zelda game and you want to get into the Zelda series, then do play this. If you HAVE played Zelda, don't play this, as it's worse than pretty much any Zelda game ever released.

Edit: Also, the music is fantastic.
